conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the path of light; shape and size depend on the light source's position.
When the light source is directly above the object, the shadow is directly below and smaller.
The light source creates elongated shadows A, B, C, and D behind the objects.
The light source is not directly above but at some angle behind the objects.
As the light source moves forward, it gets closer to being directly above the objects.
When the light source is directly above the objects, the shadows will be directly below and smaller.
Shadow A will move closer to the object and eventually be directly below it.
Shadow B will move closer to the object and end up directly below it.
Shadow C will move closer to the object and end up directly below it.
Shadow D will move closer to the object and end up directly below it.
As the light source moves forward, the angle decreases, resulting in smaller shadows.
When the light source is directly above, shadows will be the smallest, being the projection of the objects' shapes.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their objects and be directly below them; their size will decrease.
